course.subject: LIFS
course.name: Biochemistry of Nutrition
course.description: The biochemistry of major food ingredients including proteins, oil, carbohydrates, vitamins and minerals; functional and nutritional properties will be emphasized.

reviews.author: Fickdeinemutter
reviews.title: Great Course!
reviews.comment_content:
Lectured but NOT examined:

Lipids, Carbohydrates, Proteins, Alcohol, Fat-soluble Vitamins (A, D, E & K).

Examined in Final Exam:

Water-soluble Vitamins (C, B1, B2, B3, B5, B7, B9 & B12), Iron & Selenium.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Saw Dr. Wong once again since the end of LIFS 1901 in my 1st year (2015-16 Fall). I had not realized I could see him again in my final semester at UST. He taught us for the 1st month.

Teaching was handed over to Dr. Nguyen (Vietnamese) since the 2nd month.

Both teachers were kind, great & humorous.

At the last lesson on 9 May, he took group photos with us.
reviews.comment_grading:
Group Reports: 15%
Group Presentation: 25%
Final Exam: 60%

10+ persons per group. Each group must choose a topic from whatever is taught throughout the course for the presentation. DON'T neglect the preparations for the presentation!

Final Exam had both MC, SQ & LQ. Full Mark was 120. 40 marks per part.

MC asked about everything. SQ were Fill-in-the-Blanks. LQ focused on the mechanisms of actions of Water-soluble Vitamins.

You need to know the flow charts really well, especially how the vitamins are metabolised in your stomach.  

My group & I got the highest mark (36.25/40) for Presentation. The Final Exam's result is not released. I'm given a B grade. I can't tell if it is good.

Thank you so much Dr. Nguyen <3 !
reviews.comment_workload:
Group Reports & Group Presentation.

For Final Exam, there were neither past papers nor sample questions.

You need to be very familiar with all functions, deficiency-diseases & mechanisms of actions of the Water-soluble Vitamins concerned.

They'd recommend you some textbooks at the start of term. Someone sent me an electronic copy of one of them. Yet, it was voluminous & thus I found no help to my understanding of the course's content. You should go to every lesson & jot down every key point he mentions instead.

I skipped some lessons due to either laziness or job interviews. It DID have some effects on my Final Exam.

reviews.author: ashhhhhhh
reviews.title: Interesting Course!
reviews.comment_content:
Prof Wong's part:

Lipids, Carbohydrates, Proteins

Prof Nguyen's part:

Alcohol, Fat-soluble Vitamins (A, D, E & K), Water-soluble Vitamins (C, B1, B2, B3, B5, B7, B9 & B12), Iron & Selenium

Only Water-soluble Vitamins (C, B1, B2, B3, B5, B7, B9 & B12), Iron & Selenium were examined in the final exam, other topics were examined through group reports and Q&A.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Both teachers were really nice!

However, Prof. Nguyen's accent can be hard to understand at times.
reviews.comment_grading:
Presentation and report (40%): Carbohydrates & Lipid, Proteins, Alcohol, and Fat-Soluble Vitamins.
The class will be divided into four groups that will be drawn with four different topics. The student will write a scientific report on one topics. The students can write a report individually, or you can choose to team up with any students sharing the same topics to work on one report. The score will be given the same to all the students sharing the report. The report should be submitted on Canvas before the deadline. In the lectures assigned for each report, the instructors will ask 2-3 questions for each report; therefore, the students need to show up in these lectures and answer the questions.
- Minimum 1000 words.
List of 4 topics:
- Human diseases are associated with Carbohydrate or Lipid metabolism.
- Human diseases are associated with protein metabolism.
- Human diseases are associated with alcohol metabolism.
- Human diseases are associated with Fat-Soluble Vitamin - metabolism.
Hints for the presentations and reports:
- The students may present or report many nutrient-related diseases or focus on one particular disease.
- Provide a comprehensive background of the disease.
- Provide an essential nutrition biochemistry knowledge of the nutrition factor associating with the chosen disease/diseases.
- Mechanism of nutrition biochemistry and diseases.
- The involvement of other nutrients with the diseases.
- Treatment for the diseases.                             
Final Exam: 60% (closed book online exam, with MCQs + short questions)
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite light considering only 4 topics were examined in the final exams, but there is quite a lot of content to memorize, so better revise early. I revised 1 week before the exam and got A-.

reviews.author: Pinkylaucp
reviews.comment_content:
Raymond(mid term)：carbohydrate，lipid，protein
nguyen(final)：alcohol, water soluble vitamins and fat soluble vitamins, iron, selenium, iodine
reviews.comment_teaching:
Both are quite boring

Raymond reminded us what we have to study before mid term and what he said appeared exactly on the mid term paper. Most students scored high marks.

It is the first time for Nguyen to teach the course. His Vietnam accent is a bit difficult to catch up. I tried to concentrate but still failed to understand what he said. He told us that alcohol part and the structure of the vitamins were not examed only on the day before final. It would be great if he can tell us the exam coverage earlier and also precisely.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid term: 43/50(above mean)
Final: 39/55(above mean 1.5 sd)
Final grade: A
reviews.comment_workload: Not much only have to study for mid term and final
